708944f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street (West)
708944f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from 5lst Street.
Building markeo x is William K. Vanderbilt Mansion.
at extreme left are the twin Vanderbilt mansions.
The first Church is St. Thomas's Protestant-Episcopal.
This later burned and was re-built.
1900.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

708945f.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street
708945f.text:
Fifth Avenue north from 51st Street, showing Easter Sunday crowds.
Two automobiles may be seen in this picture--one, in left foreground
is south-bound, and is almost at N.W. corner of 51st Street.
The other is north-bound, and is in right centre of picture.
1903.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

708948f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street (West)
708948f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., west side, south from and including West 51st Street. Shon
across the future site of the International Building, are three units of Rock-
efeller Center; H.C.A. Building (right), British Empire Building and La Maiso
Francaise.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

730194f-a.title: General view - 5th Avenue - Southwest.
730194f-a.text:
A general view of Rockefeller Center, looking southwestward from
Fifth Ave. and West 51st Street, showing the new development under
construction. The prominent building is the 70-story R.C.A. Building,
on the west side of Rockefeller Plasa, from West 50th to West 49th
Streets. On its right appears the 31-story R.K.0. Building, on the east
side of Sixth Ave., from West 51st to West 50th Streets and preceding it
the International Music Hall.
June 14, 1933.
Brown Brothers.

713528f-a.title: Manhattan: 51st Street - 5th Avenue
713528f-a.text:
(1)
5lst Street, south side, west from west of Fifth Avenue,
with the new Rockefeller Centre in the background.
July 2, 1933
P. L. Sperr
(2)
Another view from a point closer to Fifth Avenue. Note
the Associated Press Building under construction in the vacant
space shown in View 1 and to the rear of the Radio City Music
Hall and R. K. O. Buildings. This new feature will be on the
west side of (also new) Rockefeller Plaza, extending from 50th
to 51st Street. On the left of View 1 appears a portion of the
huge International Building.
July 16, 1938
P. L. Sperr

708942f-b.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street (West)
708942f-b.text:
Home of 0eneral Cornelius Vanderbilt, N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue
and 5lst Street.
A similar house formerly adjoined it on the right, and the two were
known as the twin Vanderbilt houses.
Richard Morris Hunt was architect for the two.
April 9,1928.
P.L.Sperr,Photographer.
aEEEE:
A view mainly of the N.W. corner.
November 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

708943f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street (West)
708943f-a.text:
640 Fifth Avenue, at the N. W. corner of West 51st St.,
showing the Vanderbilt home, prior to its proposed demo-
lition. This structure has been sold to the Astor real
estete interests and who plan to erect a commercial two
story structure here. It was the first of the numerous
Vanderbilt houses in this area anc now is the last. It
was erected for Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt who became the
dominant figure in society. Recognition here connoted
social acceptance. General Cornelius Vanderbilt inherited
it at a later date.
October 26, 1940
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31at St., N.Y.C.
Neg w iooe

708915f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street
708915f-a.text:
Fifth Aoenue, east side, south from 52nd Street (right),
showing prominently the steeples being added to St.
Patricks Cathedral. This edifice was projected by
Archbishop Hughs, and the cornerstone laid in 1858. It
was opened in 1879. The steeples were added in 1888.
On the right isphe R. C. Orphan Asylum for Boys, occupy-
ing the 52nd to 5lst Street frontage. It was founded
in 1825 and incorporated in 1852. The present buildings
were completed in 1851.
Date: 1888
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708940f-b.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - 51st Street
708940f-b.text:
(1)
Union Club, Fifth Avenue at the N.E. corner of 51st Street.
This is the clubhouse built in 1902, and occupied by the
Union Club from 1903 to 1933. The block in which it is
situated used to be the site of the Roman Catholic Orphan
Asylum.
May 6, 1928.
Gift of P.  L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, a closer view, and east on the north side of 51st
Street.
October 9, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as seen across clearance for Radio City.
October 2, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
